Summary: Background: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is known as a very rare possible trigger of pericarditis. Most frequently it develops after a latent period or early in the case of periprocedural complications. In this report, we present an atypical early onset of pericarditis after an uncomplicated PCI. (1) Case summary: A 70-year-old man was admitted to our hospital with unstable angina pectoris. (2) He had undergone PCI for a left anterior descending artery (LAD) lesion.
History: A 65 @-@ year @-@ old woman arri ves to the ED complaining of chest pain . Her past medical history includes hypertension , atherosclerosis , and coronary artery disease . She underwent a coronary artery bypass graft ( CABG ) 3 weeks ago for three @-@ vessel disease . She reports that her chest pain worsen with inspiration and less when le aning forward . A friction ru is heard on a . ECG shows global ST elevation .
